title: geth does not start after upgrading from 1.3.5. to 1.4.10
body:
## Checklist
- [done ] built geth 1.4.10
- [done ] installed it over previous version (1.3.5.) (`sudo cp geth /usr/bin/geth`)
## System/environment
- OS: debian 8.3 Jessie x64, kernel version 3.16.0-4-amd64, virtual machine, running on VirtualBox, host machine Win7 x64, NAT network settings used
## Expected behaviour

**geth** should be able to launch given the following command line arguments:

`geth --datadir "./datadir" --networkid 100 --rpcapi eth,web3,personal --rpc --maxpeers 0 init "genesis.json" --etherbase "0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000" --mine --minerthreads 3`
## Observed behaviour

**geth** throws an error:

```
Incorrect Usage.

init [arguments...]

The init command initialises a new genesis block and definition for the network.
This is a destructive action and changes the network in which you will be
participating.


flag provided but not defined: -etherbase
```

Also tried launching **geth** with the init command and its arguments on the last position:

`geth --datadir "./datadir" --etherbase "0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000" --mine --minerthreads 3 --networkid 100 --rpcapi eth,web3,personal --rpc --maxpeers 0 init "genesis.json"`

 which outputs the following:

```
I0727 12:29:08.531439 ethdb/database.go:82] Alloted 16MB cache and 16 file handles to single_bootstrap_node_geth/chaindata
I0727 12:29:08.663983 core/genesis.go:92] Genesis block already in chain. Writing canonical number
I0727 12:29:08.665008 cmd/geth/main.go:299] successfully wrote genesis block and/or chain rule set: 2279317df6aed704d8d46771ed06fbe4b7a935f7005d341b091b7957bc374def
```

and **geth** does not start mining.

I don't know why the previous version that you used worked with this set of flags. Probably because the init subcommand was not fully implemented. 1.3.5 is really old. In geth 1.4.x your command line flags are odd.

The [init](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Command-Line-Options#init) subcommand is used to create a chain with a custom genesis block and is usually not used with flags apart from the datadir flag.

If you just want to start geth (on the mainnet) and let it mine drop the init subcommand. Your command would look like (replace `--etherbase "0x..."` with something that you own):

```
geth --datadir "./datadir" --etherbase "0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000" --mine --minerthreads 3 --rpcapi eth,web3,personal --rpc
```

You might want to look at the `--support-dao-fork` and `--oppose-dao-fork` flags.

If you want to create a private network. Follow the instructions on the wiki for the init subcommand and after you created the custom chain start geth with a datadir pointing to the custom chain datadir.

Thanks. I did manage to get it running on a private test net by running:

`geth --datadir "datadir" init "genesis.json"`

and then launching with:

`geth --datadir "datadir" --mine --minerthreads 3 --networkid 13 --rpcapi eth,web3,personal --rpc --maxpeers 0`

 **geth** starts mining:


The problem is that the IPC endpoint `data_dir/geth.ipc` is not reachable; running:

`geth --ipcpath "datadir/geth.ipc" attach`

gives:

`Fatal: Unable to attach to remote geth: dial unix /home/user/.ethereum/geth.ipc: connection refused`

Changing the arguments:

`geth attach datadir/geth.ipc`

gives:

`Fatal: Unable to attach to remote geth: invalid endpoint`
Above, you are (maybe unintentionally) mixing up $data_dir, data_dir and ./data_dir. What happens when you specify an absolute path like "/opt/ethereum/data_dir" everywhere?
No, the actual directory is always "data_dir" (I use a bash script to launch geth).

According to the logs the IPC endpoint is opened:
`I0728 04:00:15.151132 node/node.go:296] IPC endpoint opened: data_dir/geth.ipc`.

In the attach example you don't use the underscore in data_dir:
`geth attach datadir/geth.ipc`

Try `geth attach data_dir/geth.ipc`. Attaching should work with relative paths.
Thanks, I've managed to set it accordingly.
